digest.editor_note: Fellow Humans, Nvidia just posted a quarter that would have triggered a ticker-tape parade in any prior bull market, and the market's response was to sell the stock 5%. That tells you everything about where sentiment sits right now: expectations have outrun reality, AI capex narratives are fraying at the edges, and investors are searching for the exit before the music stops. Meanwhile, mortgage rates quietly slipped below 6% for the first time since 2022 — a data point that deserves more attention than it's getting.

sentiment.label: Cautious
sentiment.context: Nvidia's blowout earnings failed to lift markets, Bitcoin is unwinding from months of distribution, oil is drifting, and Treasury yields are edging lower — a market collectively hedging rather than committing.

stories.headline: Nvidia Falls 5% Despite Record Earnings; Nasdaq Drops 1.3% as AI Optimism Cracks
stories.body: Nvidia beat on revenue, profit, and forward guidance, and still lost 5% on the session — the Nasdaq fell 1.3% and the S&P 500 dropped 0.6% in sympathy. Investors flagged a lack of clarity on China revenue and growing anxiety over whether AI infrastructure spending is approaching a plateau. The selloff reinforces an emerging 'AI scare trade': the question is no longer whether the buildout is real, but who actually profits when it matures.

stories.headline: 30-Year Mortgage Rate Drops Below 6% for First Time Since September 2022
stories.body: Freddie Mac reported the benchmark 30-year fixed mortgage rate fell to 5.98% this week, its third consecutive weekly decline and the lowest reading in over three years. The 10-year Treasury yield sat at 4.02% at midday Thursday, continuing its gradual descent. The timing matters: the rate break arrives just as the spring homebuying season opens, though with nearly 69% of existing mortgages locked below 5%, the lock-in effect remains a structural ceiling on inventory.

stories.headline: Bitcoin's Decline Is Structural Distribution, Not Market Manipulation — Bitwise CIO
stories.body: Despite viral theories blaming Jane Street, Binance, and macro hedge funds for Bitcoin's slide into the low-$60,000s, Bitwise CIO Matt Hougan argues the move reflects months of orderly distribution followed by forced liquidation cascades once key support broke. The roughly 45% peak-to-trough drawdown fits historical mid-cycle reset patterns. Selling pressure appears to be slowing, but the damage was done well before February's sharp leg lower.

stories.headline: First U.S. Primary Aluminum Plant in 45 Years Breaks Ground in Oklahoma, Fueled by Tariff Policy
stories.body: Emirates Global Aluminum and Century Aluminum announced a new $multi-billion smeltery in Inola, Oklahoma — the first primary aluminum production facility built in the U.S. since 1980 — projected to produce 750,000 tons annually and more than double current domestic output. The project, requiring 1.2 gigawatts of continuous power and expected to generate 5,000 jobs, is a direct byproduct of the 50% tariff on steel, aluminum, and copper that survived the Supreme Court's broader tariff rollback in February. Whether this is industrial policy working or simply expensive reshoring math remains the open question.

stories.headline: Crude Settles Mixed as Geneva Iran Nuclear Talks Inject Cautious Optimism
stories.body: Oil prices ended the session in mixed territory as traders weighed cautious optimism from ongoing U.S.-Iran negotiations in Geneva against a broader risk-off backdrop in equities. Progress toward a nuclear deal would potentially return Iranian barrels to global markets, adding supply pressure at a moment when demand signals are already soft. The directional ambiguity in crude mirrors the wider market's inability to commit to a narrative.

stories.headline: Bipartisan Bill Seeks to Shield Crypto Developers from Money Transmission Liability After Tornado Cash Convictions
stories.body: Representatives Fitzgerald, Cline, and Lofgren introduced the Promoting Innovation in Blockchain Development Act of 2026, targeting 18 U.S.C. Section 1960 to explicitly exempt noncustodial software developers from federal money transmission law. The legislation is a direct response to the conviction of Tornado Cash co-founder Roman Storm in August 2025 and Samourai Wallet guilty pleas in November 2025, both of which sent a chill through DeFi development communities. The bill's bipartisan framing signals that developer liability has become a live political fault line, not just an industry grievance.

stories.headline: Solana Captures 41% of All Web3 DApp Revenue as RWA Ecosystem Hits $1.71 Billion ATH
stories.body: Despite sideways price action, Solana now accounts for over 41% of total Web3 decentralized application revenue according to data from Syndica, per a SOL Strategies report. Its real-world asset ecosystem hit a record $1.71 billion in on-chain value, up more than 45% in 30 days, reflecting accelerating institutional tokenization activity. HSDT's Pacific Backbone infrastructure initiative — connecting Seoul, Tokyo, Singapore, and Hong Kong — is the latest signal that APAC institutions are beginning to treat Solana as a settlement layer rather than a speculative token.

quote.text: Markets can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent.
quote.attribution: John Maynard Keynes, A Tract on Monetary Reform, 1923
